facts: The word "classical" often means Western art music from about 1750 to 1820, but people also use it to describe many centuries of orchestra and piano music.
A symphony is a long piece for orchestra that usually has several sections called movements, often with different moods and speeds.
Ludwig van Beethoven kept composing even after he began losing his hearing, and his Ninth Symphony was written when he was almost completely deaf.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart started performing in public as a child and wrote music in many forms, including operas, symphonies, and concertos.
An opera is a story told through singing with costumes and acting, and it often includes an orchestra playing in a pit below the stage.
In an orchestra, string instruments like violins and cellos usually make up the largest group, while woodwinds, brass, and percussion add different colors of sound.
The modern piano developed from an earlier instrument called the harpsichord, but unlike the harpsichord it can play both soft and loud notes depending on how you press the keys.
